active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the ongoing use of security questions in modern authentication: Are they a relic of poor design (citing NIST SP 800-63B's recommendation against KBA), or do they have niche value? Support with examples of real-world breaches involving answer brute-forcing.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Penetration Testing. Topic: 'Answer Brute-forcing' (Level 6 in hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Penetration Testing And Ethical Hacking > Web Application Penetration Testing > 006_Authentication Testing > Security Questions and Knowledge-Based Authentication > Answer Brute-forcing). Focus exclusively on brute-forcing answers to security questions (KBA, e.g., 'mother's maiden name'), distinguishing from password brute-forcing. Prior knowledge: Basic auth concepts. Incorporate: - Learning objectives: [PASTE FULL LIST FROM ABOVE] - Scaffolding: Distribute cards across 4 layers [PASTE FULL LAYERS]. - Active learning: Include 2-3 cards per activity type as application prompts. - Sources: NIST SP 800-63B (https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html), OWASP Authentication Cheat Sheet (https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Authentication_Cheat_Sheet.html), OWASP Testing Guide (https://owasp.org/www-project-web-security-testing-guide/), ISO 27001 A.9.4 (access control). Generate 75 flashcards using the schema: [PASTE FULL SCHEMA]. Ensure pedagogical depth: Tie to Bloom's, use examples (e.g., first pet dictionary attack), mitigations (rate limiting). Voter priorities: Completeness (full sources), pedagogy (scaffolding/Bloom's), accuracy (KBA-specific). Output ONLY a JSON array of flashcards, no extra text.
